title: Before 18 October 2016, will Iran's Guardian Council approve legislation which would restrict the use of the death penalty?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.

It's probably too late for this question, but there is movement on the issue:  "A majority of 150 lawmakers in the 290-seat parliament have reportedly endorsed a bill that would end capital punishment for drug trafficking, marking significant progress for reformists and human rights advocates who have been battling to overturn the law for years." [1] "The reform is a bold initiative in Iran, where the criminal justice system stems from Islamic sharia law, and under which drug trafficking is punishable by death. But perhaps more importantly, it is a first test for the Parliament’s moderate wing, which made historic gains in legislative elections in May. Hard-liners have already expressed their intention to fight any loosening of the law. The head of the judiciary, Sadegh Larijani, has rejected criticism against the law and instructed Iranian prosecutors to continue seeking the death penalty for drug offenders. (...) The reform will also face a legislative process riddled with hurdles. If the bill is approved by Parliament, it could still be blocked by the Guardian Council, a body controlled by Supreme Leader Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei. The country’s leader has the last word on any judicial matter in Iran, and has so far remained silent on the issue." [2] [1] http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-iran-death-penalty-20161006-snap-story.html
[2] http://www.france24.com/en/20161006-iran-death-penalty-bill-reduce-executions-rouhani

The Guardian notes that this topic remains of considerable interest to leading human rights organizations. It quotes a representative of Human Rights Watch as saying, “In 2016, Iran is yet again the regional leader in executions – at least 230 – while it continues to be a laggard in implementing illusory penal code reforms meant to bridge the gap with international standards..." 2. Human Rights Issue http://irannewsupdate.com/news/human-rights/2961-iran-s-mass-execution-of-28-fires-outrage-as-situation-worsens.html "...In a separate statement, Mohammad Mohaddessin, chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the of the National Council for Resistance of Iran (NCRI) had this to say about Tuesday’s atrocity, “The mullahs' regime is facing absolute social isolation and widespread abhorrence by the people and thus is resorting to increased executions to create a climate of fear and to prevent the possibility of a nationwide uprising.”   
He added, “More than 2,500 people have been executed in Iran under Hassan Rouhani, who falsely claimed to seek moderation. For as long as the mullahs' regime is in power, there will continue to be further executions, torture and other crimes..."

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

There are really 2 questions here, as the parliament needs to pass the bill and the Guardian Council the needs to allow it. What are the chances of the parliament passing legislation limiting the use of the death penalty before this time?
A bill was brought forward in December of 2015 to stop the use of executions for drug-related offences (https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2015/12/bill-to-end-death-penalty-for-drug-crimes/). However there’s no evidence that this bill has been properly discussed or considered (as I understand it actual consideration of the bill relies on approval from other elements of the Iranian regime). Essentially I think this issue comes down to will on the part of the Iranian regime (President, Guardian Council) rather than the Parliament, the Parliament itself is fairly weak and unlikely to pass such a controversial bill without the will of the more powerful elements of the Iranian government. Various sources (https://majlismonitor.com/en/2016/03/analysis-2016-iranian-parliamentary-assembly-of-experts-election-results/) and (http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/03/iran-election-results-winner/472128/) suggest the Parliament is currently a mixture of conservative and moderate members. But one expert (Karim Sadjadpour of the Carnegie Endowment) suggests that ‘the new parliament will support President Rouhani in promoting Iran’s economic reform and development and will focus less on divisive issues such as political and social change.’ I think the time frame also really limits the likelihood here so I’ll start it off at 5%. What are the chances of the Guardian Council accepting any legislation?
Again, I think these two different questions are linked ie. it’s unlikely that a bill will reach the Guardian Council without the Council having already agreed/supported it. 

I’ll start off with 5% but I would have to see significant development to not bring it closer to 0% in the next month.
No signs that this is becoming more likely, so reducing prediction.

It seems more likely that the Iranian government restrict the use of death penalty on drug trafficking. 
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/28/iran-under-pressure-abolish-death-penalty-drug-trafficking
Politics might be at play here. Lifting death penalty is a symbol of western progress in civil society. I am not positive that Iran is so ready to be part of this ideology.
The term of restrict the use seem quite loose

https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2015/12/bill-to-end-death-penalty-for-drug-crimes/
If it hasn't moved in the majles since Dec the chances of the equivalent of an upper house passing it by October are pretty slim just on time grounds. 
Then add in ideology etc and this probability comes down even further
Iran needs much more time and cultural change in order to restrict use of death penalty.

Iran's politics move too slowly for this.  The opposition to the legislation is religious-based.  The first hurdle is getting it through the Majles.  On paper, the moderate-reformist coalition is in charge.  In truth, its center is moderate conservative.  Even if the Majles approves, the GC will likely hold it up on technicalities.  It will just be another "razieh": a Shi'ite passion play.  The real decisionmaker is the Supreme Leader Khamanei who has taken very conservative stances.

Gut instinct.  The legislation will pass, but after 18 October 2016.  Likely within ten years, but after international events further empower females around the world which infuses more compassionate discussions in relation to children.

There seems to be little genuine appetite for this amongst the Iranian leadership. The use of the death penalty, and the terror that it spreads, has been a cornerstone of Iranian government control since the revolution. Even the reformist Rouhani has done little to agitate in favour of its limitation. Indeed, there is some reason to think that, since his appointment in 2013, the frequency of executions in Iran has actually increased (with 2015 being a particularly bloody year). Moreover, getting the Majles to consider (very publically) an apparently liberalising policy which then does not get past the Guardian Council is a common tactic in Iran - it is an effective, low-risk ploy used by the regime as propaganda both internally and externally to demonstrate their apparent 'openness' to new ideas. It seems unlikely, at this stage, that the death penalty would be reformed in Iran - the regime has little to gain and much to lose from doing this. Currently, the only factor that convinces me to raise my prediction beyond 10% is Iran's current international rehabilitation; renewed oil sales have boosted the Iranian economy, and the leadership is desperate to have greater influence on international markets. If an apparently 'liberalising' domestic move could buy Iran greater diplomatic and economic influence globally, then it may seem appealing to the leadership. However, this factor does not seem decisive (and, if anything, Iran has most to gain in terms of influencing oil markets from establishing a common purpose with its rival, Saudi Arabia; reforming capital punishment is not going to have any effect here).

Unlikely in this time span.  The hardliners are experiencing a boom in blowback to the deal.  Additionally, the RG's control of the economy and means of production will not allow Liberals to reap any benefits this quickly.  It'll happen, but much more slowly.
Even if they agree to soften their stance in their war on drugs (to secure more western aid), it will probably informal, not legislative.
The Guardian Council wouldn't pass anything that goes against the religion

This is a broadly worded question.  Even if the legislation mentioned in the question doesn't pass, it is possible that some unrelated legislation restricting the death penalty in marginal cases could pass.  The confidence of other forecasters doesn't seem warranted.

The religious laws are very key components of Iranian system. The Guardian Council is mostly nominated from hardliners because there is a veto rights to disband moderate candidates. Memebers of Guardian Council have to be dedicated to islamic values so it leaves no room for reformists. I am keen to belive that Iran will still keep Islam laws so important that no big changes will happen to 18. 2016. Also most death penalties are related to drugs and i dont believe there will be any change that either.  The amount of death penalties has grown big since 2010. That will also be negative factor if we consider the change in this issue.
Such a step will probably be a little too radical for them

Interestingly, there is the possibility of the Majles passing such legislation, the Guardian Council rejecting it but then another council, the 'Expediency Council' passing it - as I understand this latter council seems to have the final say in this matter. I don't know if there is any overlap between the Guardian Council and the Expediency Council. In a slightly older article: https://www.politicshome.com/news/uk/foreign-affairs/news/73031/alex-salmond-helps-broker-moves-end-death-penalty-iran
Alex Salmond, former SNP leader, has seen signs of interest From Iran:
".... Iranian foreign minister Mohammad Jafad Zarif told Mr Salmond that his country wanted to explore "alternative" punishments for the crime and was keen to discuss it with Europe.   In an interview with The House magazine , Mr Salmond said: "His logic was that 85% of capital punishment in Iran is drug trafficking. He said there’s nothing in Sharia Law that says we must have capital punishment for these offences. Therefore, he said they are willing to have an open dialogue on alternative deterrents, bearing in mind it’s in the interests of Europe not to have an acceleration of the drug trade through Iran into Europe." In addition Iran has signed international agreements which could be motivation to modify aspects of the laws.
"He urged the authorities to ensure that no one is executed for offences committed under the age of 18, stressing that there is a strict prohibition against the execution of juvenile offenders in international human rights law, including in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Iran ratified in 1975 and the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which it ratified in 1994."

The death penalty in Iran is rooted deeply in both Iranian religion and culture. In religious terms the argument for the death penalty is pretty clear: the Koran prescribes it and Iran is essentially a theocracy in which religious clerics have control over the levers of power.
Culturally, there isn't a great deal of mainstream opposition to the death penalty and the population (in general) and politicians see it as both a punishment and an integral mechanism for deterring future criminal activity.

The Guardian Council has twelve members, six theologians appointed directly by the Supreme Leader, and another six jurists nominated by the judiciary.  It has a very conservative mindset, as was seen in the recent Majles elections when it disqualified almost all of the candidates considered to  be moderate or reformist. It can be taken for granted that anyone nominated by the current Supreme Leader will be very conservative. Similarly, the judiciary is a very conservative institution too and so will its nominees be. In my opinion, the chances of the Guardian Council approving legislation within the next four months, restricting the death penalty as presently applied, is almost nil. The 1% is there just in case they do decide to make an exception for juveniles.

How many people are executed every year in Iran? The Iranian authorities have executed more than 700 people so far in 2015. 
https://www.amnesty.org/en/press-releases/2015/11/iran-death-penalty-facts/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Iran

Offhand, not much reason to believe that such legislation would get the okey-dokey from the cognizant poobahs.  It is possible to suspect that they think they've given away too much already.  This may happen after a while, but not probable before this date.

In recent open sources it was indicated that in Iran, emerging from isolation after the lifting of nuclear-related sanctions, at least 977 people were executed in 2015, up 31% from the 2014 figure of at least 743. The vast majority were for drug-related offences. Iran is one of the last executioners of child offenders, in violation of international law. Last year it executed at least four people who were under 18 at the time of their crime.  In states that have a high application of the death penalty, primarily for drug offenses in Islamic countries include:  China, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam, Indonesia.  However, China (which currently has the highest death penalty rate), Singapore and Vietnam also implement policies for reasons of drug offenses of various kinds. A 1988 Convention formalized transnational cooperation in drug control and essentially ‘internationalizing’ the war on drugs.  In practice, this means a border control program between Iran and Pakistan could involve European Union donors, German police trainers, French equipment and British intelligence delivered in partnerships coordinated by the United Nations. Thus what happens in Iran is influenced by decisions made in Brussels, to say nothing of the international bodies interposed in this arrangement. When hundreds of people are executed for drugs in Iran—a country that receives millions in drug control aid— every
year, it becomes impossible to dismiss these events as incidental ‘unintended consequences’ of drug control because so many parties are engaged in the context. The death penalty is not ‘unintended’ in Iran, and executions implicate the government’s international counterparts. Iran has had capital punishment for drug offenses since the 1940s and 1950s.   The following law is in effect in Iran along with the data for executions between 2012 - 2014.   580 (of which 439 were for drug offenses) executions in 2012, 687 (of which 331 were for drug offenses) executions in 2013, and 753 (of which 367 have been for drug offense) executions in 2013.  Executions for murder has also been on the rise over the last three year period in Iran.   Acknowledging the difficulties of obtain completely accurate data in Iran, the previously specified data can be considered moderately high in its accuracy. Given the theocratic nature of governance along with Sharia Law, we will not see a relaxation of death penalty laws or any significant changes by the Guardian Council on this issue anytime soon.  If fact, the data indicates that executions have been on the rise, and is anticipated by regressed predictions, to continue over the next number of years.  Restriction of the use of death penalty does not seem to occur into other domains that are not considered 'reasonable' by Islamic Law.  However, if anything, one can anticipate an expansion of the use in other areas rather than constraint.  Executions by Iran is not considered by area experts to be "unintended."  While it is possible that there might be some relaxation of the execution of juvenile delinquents.  In fact, one can expect with a reasonably high degree that Iran keeps their juvenile offenders on death row (until ready for execution (despite international law indicating that crimes committed [at the time of offense] before juvenile turn 18) until execution dates are determined.   Data on execution of juveniles in Iran # : Global juveniles  #.  2010 (1:1), 2011 (7:7), 2012 (4:5), 2013 (9:12), 2014 (12:12), 2015 (4:9).  This data does not include the global total of executions for each year.  It is restricted to demonstrate Iran's # executions of juveniles relative to other countries.  So for 2015, 4 juveniles were executed in Iran with a total of 9 global juvenile executions (without specifying country of origin). My assertion that we can expect no relaxation in the laws by the Guardian Council, requiring execution (either by adults or juveniles) to change within the near future.  In other words one can expect a longer horizon on such deviations from current Iranian Law.
